channel.title: Flaws in PI
channel.description: What are the flaws specifically in PI? I am not a PI fan (I work slower with PI than with Hyperion), I'm just wondering, what flaws are in the source?

item.dc:creator: @F_A_I_L_S Fails
item.description:

i just lost my respect for you because you don’t know sarcasm when yew c it.

item.title: Flaws in PI
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Jmood, post:30, topic:500383”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=618612.msg4249260#msg4249260 date=1362246868]

I can go on forever with this list:

  • Awful, I mean awful packet handling.
  • The RS2 stream buffer’s capacity never expands when it’s close to being full (thus causing all the runtime exceptions, nulls, and what not)
  • Very outdated
  • Mix & matched networking bits (using byte[] oriented buffer instead of Mina [it’s default networking] oriented)
  • All the code has flaws, I mean come on, I shouldn’t be able to edit one line literally in the client and be able to go invisible, no-clip, or spawn myself items.
  • No evidence of anyone who programmed the base knowing anything useful, i.e design patterns, etc.
  • It’s in no way scalable or robust.

…

WinterLove wasn’t made to look good, it was made to exploit and show proofs of concept so your second to last line isn’t needed at all. if you guys want a better base then either build your self one or use a more modern framework. It’s pretty stupid that everyone bashes WinterLove when the server wasn’t even build for hosting, yet you compare it as such…

I’m leaning towards a concept where someone would develop off of it and host it, not proof of concept, I’m well aware of why wL was made and what it was meant for. Are you like out to get me or something? It seems like every time I post, you post afterwards trying to bash what I have said.
[/quote]

I am not bashing you at all. PI isn’t a concept or even a good code base to attempt a host able server, the server is plagued by years and years of crappy patches that do nothing except bloat the code base even more.

Lets see now…

Lots of legacy code
Null pointers
Useless code
Bad code
Run time exceptions
Horrible design pattern
Weird nameing
Out dated
Bad naming
Unused files
Nothing is done properly e.g. some of the stuff needs to be deprecated but its not?
Full of dups
Stability issues

Want me to carry on?

don’t forget synchronization issues.

What? PI doesn’t have any issues with synchronization unless you mean all locks they added, I have no clue why a person would add a bunch of synchronization when the server is almost entirely single threaded…[/quote]

I was gonna say that, but I though it might of been retarded if I was wrong haha

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws in PI
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:23, topic:500383”]- The RS2 stream buffer’s capacity never expands when it’s close to being full (thus causing all the runtime exceptions, nulls, and what not)[/quote]The buffer shouldn’t go over the 5000 default limit anyway. If it gets close, you should stop parsing/creating packets until the next cycle.

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws in PI
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:28, topic:500383”][quote author=Jmood link=topic=618612.msg4248226#msg4248226 date=1362198085]

I can go on forever with this list:

  • Awful, I mean awful packet handling.
  • The RS2 stream buffer’s capacity never expands when it’s close to being full (thus causing all the runtime exceptions, nulls, and what not)
  • Very outdated
  • Mix & matched networking bits (using byte[] oriented buffer instead of Mina [it’s default networking] oriented)
  • All the code has flaws, I mean come on, I shouldn’t be able to edit one line literally in the client and be able to go invisible, no-clip, or spawn myself items.
  • No evidence of anyone who programmed the base knowing anything useful, i.e design patterns, etc.
  • It’s in no way scalable or robust.

…

WinterLove wasn’t made to look good, it was made to exploit and show proofs of concept so your second to last line isn’t needed at all. if you guys want a better base then either build your self one or use a more modern framework. It’s pretty stupid that everyone bashes WinterLove when the server wasn’t even build for hosting, yet you compare it as such…
[/quote]

I’m leaning towards a concept where someone would develop off of it and host it, not proof of concept, I’m well aware of why wL was made and what it was meant for. Are you like out to get me or something? It seems like every time I post, you post afterwards trying to bash what I have said.[/quote]

I am not bashing you at all. PI isn’t a concept or even a good code base to attempt a host able server, the server is plagued by years and years of crappy patches that do nothing except bloat the code base even more.

[quote=“Fire capez, post:29, topic:500383”][quote author=Arcik link=topic=618612.msg4247496#msg4247496 date=1362157242]
Lets see now…

Lots of legacy code
Null pointers
Useless code
Bad code
Run time exceptions
Horrible design pattern
Weird nameing
Out dated
Bad naming
Unused files
Nothing is done properly e.g. some of the stuff needs to be deprecated but its not?
Full of dups
Stability issues

Want me to carry on?
[/quote]

don’t forget synchronization issues.[/quote]

What? PI doesn’t have any issues with synchronization unless you mean all locks they added, I have no clue why a person would add a bunch of synchronization when the server is almost entirely single threaded…

Read full topic

item.title: Flaws in PI
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

No, PI really does have just about everything wrong with it that possibly could be wrong. I’m not a java programmer but anyone who can read code should realise this, language regardless. It’s a fractal of bad design. If I was to ever use anything remotely close to PI I’d go back to the Emulous framework, which is what PI was based off before all of the really terrible code was added :P.

Read full topic
